definitions: elected body that creates laws and governs a nation or state
formal meeting period when parliament assembles to conduct legislative business
examples: Parliament voted overwhelmingly to approve the new education reform bill
The British Parliament consists of the House of Commons and Lords
Parliament will reconvene after the summer recess in September
During this parliament, major constitutional changes were debated and passed

definitions: elected or appointed member serving in a parliament or legislative body
expert in parliamentary procedure and rules who advises legislative proceedings
examples: The parliamentarian defended her controversial vote during the press conference
Several parliamentarians crossed party lines to support the healthcare bill
The parliamentarian ruled that the amendment was out of order
They consulted the parliamentarian about proper debate protocol and procedures

definitions: formal room in a house for receiving and entertaining guests
business establishment providing specific services like beauty or funeral arrangements
examples: They served afternoon tea in the Victorian parlor every Sunday
The antique piano stood prominently in the front parlor
She visited the beauty parlor for her monthly hair appointment
The funeral parlor handled all arrangements with dignity and care

definitions: formal room in a house for receiving and entertaining guests
business establishment providing specific services like beauty or funeral arrangements
examples: The guests gathered in the parlour for evening entertainment
Victorian parlours were decorated with heavy curtains and ornate furniture
The massage parlour offered various therapeutic treatments and relaxation services
She opened a small ice cream parlour downtown last summer

definitions: creative work that humorously imitates another work's style for comic effect
something so poorly done it unintentionally mocks what it attempts
examples: The comedy show featured a brilliant parody of popular superhero movies
His parody of the president's speech went viral on social media
The trial became a parody of justice with its obvious bias
Their attempt at luxury was a parody of true elegance

definitions: supervised early release from prison based on good behavior and conditions
system of honor where prisoners promise to follow specific behavioral rules
examples: He was granted parole after serving eight years of his sentence
The parole board meets monthly to review eligible prisoners' cases
Breaking parole conditions results in immediate return to prison custody
The parole system aims to help prisoners reintegrate into society successfully

definitions: decorative wooden flooring made from small pieces arranged in geometric patterns
main floor seating area in a theater between orchestra and balcony
examples: The ballroom featured beautiful oak parquet in a herringbone pattern
They restored the original parquet flooring hidden under old carpet
We had excellent parquet seats for the Broadway musical performance
The parquet section offers better views than the rear mezzanine

definitions: colorful tropical bird with curved beak known for mimicking human speech
person who repeats others' words or ideas without understanding them
examples: The African grey parrot learned over two hundred different words
Wild parrots gathered noisily in the rainforest canopy each morning
He's just a parrot repeating whatever the boss says
Don't be a parrot; think critically about the information yourself

definitions: defensive action in combat sports to deflect or block an attack
skillful avoidance or deflection of a difficult question or criticism
examples: The fencer executed a perfect parry before launching her counterattack
He taught them basic parry techniques in the martial arts class
The politician's parry of tough questions frustrated the interviewing journalists
Her witty parry deflected attention from the uncomfortable topic entirely

definitions: computer program that analyzes text structure according to formal grammar rules
person who analyzes and breaks down language or text systematically
examples: The XML parser processed the data file in milliseconds efficiently
They developed a new parser for the programming language's compiler
As a skilled parser of legal documents, she found the loophole
The literary parser examined every word choice in the ancient text

definitions: extreme unwillingness to spend money or use resources even when necessary
principle favoring the simplest scientific explanation with fewest assumptions possible
examples: His parsimony meant the family lived without basic comforts unnecessarily
The company's parsimony with employee benefits hurt morale and retention
Following parsimony, scientists chose the simpler evolutionary theory over complex alternatives
Occam's razor embodies the principle of parsimony in philosophical reasoning

definitions: green leafy herb with fresh flavor used in cooking worldwide
decorative green plant traditionally used to garnish plates and dishes
examples: She chopped fresh parsley to sprinkle over the pasta dish
The recipe calls for two tablespoons of dried parsley leaves
The chef artistically placed parsley sprigs around the grilled salmon
Remove the parsley garnish before eating the main course

definitions: Protestant clergyman, especially Anglican, responsible for a parish congregation
any Christian minister or member of clergy serving a local church
examples: The village parson delivered sermons every Sunday morning without fail
The old parson had served the rural community for forty years
They invited the parson to bless their new home warmly
The parson counseled troubled parishioners with wisdom and compassion daily

definitions: house provided by a church for its minister or parson to live
examples: The Victorian parsonage stood next to the village church gracefully
They renovated the old parsonage to accommodate the minister's large family
Living in the parsonage meant being constantly available to parishioners
The church committee maintains the parsonage as part of clergy compensation

definitions: part or fragment of something that is not complete or whole
unfair bias or preference shown toward particular people or things
examples: The insurance company sent a partial payment for the claim
We only received partial results from the laboratory testing yesterday
The judge showed obvious partial treatment favoring the prosecution throughout
Her partial for chocolate desserts was well known among friends

definitions: unfair bias in favor of one person or thing over others
particular fondness or preference for something based on personal taste
examples: The referee's partiality toward the home team angered visiting fans
Accusations of partiality led to the judge's removal from the case
Her partiality for Italian cuisine influenced every restaurant choice made
His well-known partiality for jazz shaped the radio station's programming

definitions: person who takes active part in an activity, event, or study
examples: Every participant received a certificate after completing the training workshop
The study recruited two hundred participants for the clinical trial
Tournament participants must register online before the deadline next Friday
Active participants contributed more than passive observers to group discussions

definitions: act of taking part or becoming involved in an activity or event
examples: Student participation in class discussions improves learning outcomes significantly
Her participation in community service earned recognition from the mayor
Voter participation reached record levels during the presidential election campaign
The program encourages participation from all community members regardless of background

definitions: grammatical form of verb functioning as adjective or part of compound tenses
examples: The past participle 'broken' describes the window's current state
English uses present participles ending in -ing for continuous tenses
Students struggled with irregular participles like 'sung' and 'written'
The participle phrase 'running quickly' modified the subject effectively

definitions: extremely small piece of matter or substance often invisible individually
fundamental unit of matter smaller than atoms in physics
short word in grammar that doesn't change form but affects meaning
examples: Dust particles floated visibly in the afternoon sunlight streaming inside
The air filter removes harmful particles from the ventilation system
Scientists discovered a new subatomic particle at the research facility
Particle physics explores the fundamental building blocks of the universe
The particle 'up' changes meaning in the phrasal verb 'give up'
Japanese particles indicate grammatical relationships between words in sentences

definitions: quality of being very detailed, exact, or concerned with specific details
distinctive characteristic or feature that makes something unique or special
examples: She described the event with such particularity that listeners felt present
The lawyer's particularity about contract wording prevented future disputes entirely
Each region's wine has particularities reflecting local soil and climate
The particularity of her artistic style made her work instantly recognizable

definitions: minute separate particle of matter suspended in air or liquid
relating to or consisting of minute separate particles of matter
examples: The factory installed filters to reduce particulate emissions into the atmosphere
Particulate matter in urban air poses serious health risks to residents
The particulate nature of the substance made filtration necessary
Scientists measured particulate pollution levels throughout the metropolitan area daily

definitions: act or moment of leaving or separating from someone or something
line or place where something divides, especially hair on the head
examples: Their emotional parting at the airport brought tears to everyone watching
The parting of ways came after twenty years of partnership
She styled her hair with a side parting for the formal event
The parting in his hair was always perfectly straight and neat

definitions: strong supporter of a party, cause, or person, often blindly loyal
member of armed resistance group fighting against occupying forces secretly
examples: Partisan supporters refused to acknowledge any flaws in their candidate
The media criticized partisan politics dividing the country along party lines
World War Two partisans sabotaged enemy supply lines behind occupied territories
The partisan fighters lived in mountain hideouts during the resistance

definitions: strong, sometimes blind support for a particular party or cause over others
examples: Extreme partisanship prevented Congress from passing necessary bipartisan legislation
The judge's obvious partisanship undermined public trust in the ruling
Media partisanship shapes how different audiences perceive the same events
Rising partisanship threatens democratic institutions and civil discourse nationally

definitions: physical structure like a wall that divides space into separate areas
act of dividing something into parts or the state of being divided
section or part created by dividing something into separate portions
examples: They installed a glass partition to create private office spaces
The folding partition allowed the room to be reconfigured quickly
The partition of India in 1947 created two separate nations
Hard drive partition helps organize data and improve system performance
Each partition of the inheritance went to different family members
The database partition improved query performance and data management significantly

definitions: process of dividing something into distinct parts or sections systematically
computing technique of dividing databases or storage into manageable segments
examples: The partitioning of the large warehouse created specialized storage areas
Careful partitioning of responsibilities prevented overlap between departments effectively
Database partitioning improved query speed by organizing data more efficiently
The partitioning strategy distributed workload across multiple servers evenly

definitions: variant spelling of partisan meaning strong supporter of a cause
historical weapon consisting of long shaft with broad blade attachment
examples: The partizan crowds cheered wildly for their political candidate
Partizan journalism lacks objectivity and balanced reporting of events
Medieval guards carried partizans as both ceremonial and functional weapons
The museum displayed an ornate partizan from the Renaissance period

definitions: person who shares ownership or participates in a business venture together
person in a committed romantic or domestic relationship with another
person who participates with another in an activity or endeavor
examples: She became a senior partner at the law firm last year
Business partners must trust each other to succeed long-term
My partner and I celebrated our tenth anniversary in Paris
They've been partners for five years and just bought a house
Choose a lab partner who shares your commitment to excellence
Her tennis partner helped improve her doubles game significantly

definitions: legal arrangement where parties agree to cooperate in advancing mutual interests
state of being partners or working together toward common goals
examples: They formed a limited partnership to purchase the commercial property
The partnership agreement outlined each party's responsibilities and profit share
The partnership between the two organizations benefited both communities greatly
Their creative partnership produced several award-winning films over the years

definitions: medium-sized game bird with brown plumage, hunted for sport and food
examples: The hunter spotted a partridge hiding in the undergrowth nearby
Roasted partridge appeared on the restaurant's seasonal game menu
A covey of partridges flew up from the wheat field suddenly
The famous Christmas song mentions a partridge in a pear tree

definitions: social event where people gather for celebration or entertainment purposes
organized political group with shared ideology seeking governmental power
person or group involved in a legal agreement or dispute
group of people traveling or working together for a purpose
examples: The birthday party lasted until midnight with dancing and games
We're hosting a dinner party for twelve guests on Saturday
The Democratic Party won a majority in the recent elections
Third parties rarely succeed in the two-party political system
Both parties signed the contract after lengthy negotiations were completed
The injured party filed a lawsuit seeking damages for negligence
The search party found the missing hikers after two days
A party of tourists arrived at the hotel this morning

definitions: SI unit of pressure equal to one newton per square meter
structured programming language developed for teaching programming concepts systematically
examples: Atmospheric pressure at sea level equals approximately 101,325 pascals
The tire pressure gauge displayed measurements in both pascals and PSI
Students learned Pascal before moving on to more complex programming languages
The Pascal compiler detected several syntax errors in the submitted code

definitions: section or excerpt from a written work or musical composition
act of moving through or past something on a journey
narrow way allowing access between buildings or rooms
process of approving legislation through voting in governmental bodies
examples: The teacher read a passage from Shakespeare to the literature class
This passage contains the main theme of the entire novel
The ship's passage through the storm tested the crew's skills
Safe passage through enemy territory required careful planning and timing
A narrow passage connected the two ancient buildings underground mysteriously
The secret passage led from the library to the wine cellar
The bill's passage through Congress took longer than expected
Passage of the amendment requires a two-thirds majority vote

definitions: corridor or path that connects different areas allowing movement between them
examples: The narrow passageway between buildings provided a shortcut to downtown
Emergency passageways must remain clear of obstacles at all times
Ancient passageways beneath the castle connected various chambers and dungeons
The ship's passageways were barely wide enough for two people

definitions: person traveling in a vehicle but not driving or operating it
examples: All passengers must fasten seatbelts before the plane takes off
The bus can accommodate fifty passengers comfortably on long trips
Passenger safety remains the airline's top priority every single flight
The taxi driver helped elderly passengers with their luggage courteously

definitions: player who throws the ball to teammates in sports
person who passes by or moves past a location
examples: The quarterback is considered the best passer in professional football
An accurate passer can change the entire game's momentum quickly
A passer on the street stopped to help with directions
Several passers witnessed the accident and called for emergency help

definitions: person who happens to be passing by a place, especially on foot
examples: A helpful passerby called an ambulance after witnessing the accident
Several passersby stopped to watch the street performer's amazing show
The lost tourist asked a passerby for directions to the museum
Passersby often pause to admire the beautiful window displays downtown

definitions: death of a person, especially when expressed with respectful language
action of going past something or someone in motion
brief or temporary occurrence that doesn't last long
examples: The community mourned the passing of their beloved longtime mayor
Her passing left a void in the arts community
The passing of the storm brought clear skies and cooler temperatures
Drivers must signal before passing slower vehicles on the highway
It was just a passing thought that didn't merit serious consideration
His passing interest in photography never developed into a hobby

definitions: powerful feeling of love, anger, or other intense emotion
strong enthusiasm or dedication for an activity or subject
suffering and death of Jesus Christ in Christian theology
examples: Their passion for each other remained strong after decades together
She spoke with passion about environmental conservation and climate change
His passion for vintage cars led to an impressive collection
Teaching is her true passion, not just a job
The church performed the Passion play every Easter weekend traditionally
Bach's St. Matthew Passion remains a masterpiece of sacred music

definitions: grammatical construction where the subject receives rather than performs action
accepting or allowing without active response or resistance
examples: The passive voice emphasizes the action rather than the actor
Students practiced converting active sentences into passive construction correctly
His passive response to criticism frustrated his supportive colleagues greatly
Passive acceptance of injustice allows problems to persist and grow

definitions: quality of accepting or allowing events without active response or resistance
examples: Her passivity in meetings meant her ideas were never heard
The citizens' passivity allowed corruption to flourish unchecked for years
Breaking free from passivity requires conscious effort and deliberate practice
His passivity masked deep-seated fears about confrontation and conflict

definitions: official government document certifying identity and citizenship for international travel
something that enables or gives access to a desired goal
examples: Remember to renew your passport before planning any international trips
The immigration officer carefully examined each passenger's passport at customs
Education is often called a passport to better employment opportunities
Her language skills were a passport to international business success

definitions: secret word or phrase used to gain access to computer systems
examples: Create a strong password using letters, numbers, and special characters
The system requires password changes every ninety days for security
Never share your password with anyone, even technical support staff
Two-factor authentication provides extra security beyond just a password

definitions: Italian food made from wheat flour dough formed into various shapes
examples: Fresh pasta tastes significantly better than the dried store-bought varieties
The restaurant serves twelve different types of homemade pasta daily
She learned to make pasta from her Italian grandmother's recipes
Whole wheat pasta provides more fiber than regular white pasta

definitions: thick, soft mixture of a substance with liquid
sticky substance used for attaching paper or other materials together
computer operation inserting copied or cut content into a document
examples: Mix flour and water to form a smooth paste consistency
The recipe requires tomato paste for a rich, concentrated flavor
Children used paste to attach pictures in their art projects
The wallpaper paste must dry completely before painting over it
Copy the text and paste it into the new document
The paste function stopped working after the software update

definitions: soft colored chalk or crayon used for drawing and art
pale, soft shade of a color with low saturation
examples: The artist created stunning portraits using oil pastels exclusively
Soft pastels blend more easily than oil pastels on paper
The nursery was decorated in soothing pastel pink and blue
Spring fashion featured pastel colors like lavender and mint green

definitions: process of heating liquids to kill harmful bacteria while preserving nutritional value
examples: Pasteurization makes milk safe to drink by eliminating dangerous pathogens
The dairy industry relies on pasteurization to extend product shelf life
Wine undergoes pasteurization to prevent spoilage during storage and shipping
Flash pasteurization preserves more nutrients than traditional heating methods

definitions: artistic work imitating the style of other works or artists
mixture of different things combined together without clear organization
examples: The novel is a clever pastiche of Victorian detective fiction
His paintings are pastiche works borrowing from multiple artistic movements
The building's architecture is a pastiche of different historical styles
The film was criticized as a pastiche lacking original vision

definitions: activity done regularly for enjoyment rather than work or necessity
examples: Reading mystery novels became her favorite pastime during retirement years
Baseball is often called America's national pastime for historical reasons
Gardening serves as both a productive pastime and stress relief
His expensive pastime of collecting rare coins required substantial investment
